Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was restocking the ambulance’s first-aid kit, carefully checking expiration dates and counting bandages, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from my husband: “Can we talk tonight? You seemed distant lately. I’m worried.” My heart tightened. He always expected us to share our worries, to be open, especially when something was bothering one of us. I glanced at the half-checked kit, knowing my shift was almost over, but protocol demanded every item be accounted for—lives could depend on it. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in. My husband needed me to be present, to listen and share, but my duty as an ambulance driver meant I couldn’t leave until the kit was perfect. I stared at the phone, torn between the urge to rush home and the responsibility to finish my check. The clock ticked, and I felt the tension growing, caught between the expectations of being a good wife and a reliable ambulance driver.
